questions.text: The parents of a neonate diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia come with queries about the disease. They have been told that it's an inherited condition and ask you how is it possible for the baby to be affected when neither of the parents are. What is the mode of inheritance of the disease?
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia / adrenogenital syndrome follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Depending on the enzyme that is deficient, patients will have :

  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia) or excess (hypernatremia, hypokalemia)
  • Incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in males
  • Virilization or sexual infantilism in females

questions.text: A baby delivered at home was born with ambiguous genitalia. The parents could not identify the sex of the child. The baby was diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is this child most likely to have?
questions.solution:
This child is most likely to have a 21-hydroxylase deficiency as it is the most common enzyme deficiency implicated in congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The second most common is 11 beta-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase enzyme hydroxylates progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to yield 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol, respectively. They help in the synthesis of aldosterone and cortisol. Therefore, the deficiency of this enzyme leads to the deficiencies of aldosterone and cortisol.

Also, the accumulated steroid precursors are diverted into the pathway for androgen (testosterone) production.

Clinical profile in 21-hydroxylase deficiency:

  • Aldosterone deficiency: Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis)
  • Cortisol deficiency: Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock
  • Androgens excess: Virilization of females and precocious puberty in males

questions.text: Which of the following types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia is not due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Under virilizing type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is not caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Depending on the extent of enzyme deficiency, CAH caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency is broadly classified into classic and non-classic forms:

Classic forms can be of two types - salt-wasting and simple virilizing types.

  • Salt-wasting type is the severe form in which both cortisol and aldosterone are deficient, with excess androgen production.
  • In the simple virilizing type, there is an impaired synthesis of cortisol and adequate amounts of aldosterone. Here, clinical features are due to the overproduction of androgens.

The non-classic form is characterized by partial 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Cortisol and aldosterone are produced normally, but at the expense of producing excess androgens.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 15-day old baby to you with complaints of decreased activity and vomiting. On examination, the baby is hypotensive, has depressed fontanelles and reduced skin turgor. The image of the external genitalia of the baby is shown below. Which electrolyte abnormality can you expect to see in this baby?
questions.solution:
The image shows ambiguous genitalia. This along with signs of dehydration and hypotension suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) can be seen in this condition. 

These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

questions.text: Investigation of choice to diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency is estimation of ____________ levels.
questions.solution:
17-hydroxyprogesterone levels estimation is the investigation of choice to diagnose CAH due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency. It will be markedly elevated.

Other findings include:

  1. Elevated androstenedione and testosterone (in females).
  2. Low cortisol and aldosterone.
  3. Elevated ACTH levels.

questions.text: You see Sanjay who is a known case of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, on steroid therapy in the ER with vomiting and fever. You administer double the regular dose of steroids. Which drug is being referred to here?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone, which is the mainstay treatment for commonest type of CAH, is the drug referred to in the given clinical scenario.

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as infection or surgery.

Glucocorticoid replacement therapy with hydrocortisone, 15-20 mg/m²/24 h, orally, in 3 divided doses is continued lifelong.

Mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone is used for patients with the salt-wasting disease. The daily dose of fludrocortisone in infants is higher than that in older children.

questions.text: The autopsy image of a baby who died during the neonatal period is shown below. Parents of the child undergo genetic counseling regarding future pregnancies. When should the mother be started on steroids in a future pregnancy?

choices.text: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
After karyotyping and determination of sex of the baby

questions.solution:
The autopsy image shows a bilaterally enlarged adrenal gland (white arrows) with a history of death during the neonatal period (probably due to shock, cardiac arrhythmias) which is suggestive of CAH in the baby. Mothers with a previously affected child of CAH should be started with steroid therapy as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed. Since it is an autosomal recessive disorder, there is a risk of the subsequent children being affected.

Dexamethasone at 20 μg/kg is started to suppress the secretion of steroids by the fetal adrenals (including adrenal androgens) and prevent the virilization of the external genitals in affected females. Then, chorionic villus biopsy is performed to determine the sex and genotype of the fetus, and therapy is continued only if the fetus is an affected female.

questions.text: You see Sathya, an adolescent in the endocrinology clinic referred by his family physician. He was told by his parents that he was a boy, but he felt differently. As he grew up, he felt increasingly uncomfortable with his identity and this caused him a great deal of sadness and isolation. On examination, he is hypertensive and has genitalia resembling a female phenotype. After karyotyping, you diagnose him with 46XY DSD. Which of the following enzyme deficiency would be in your differential?
questions.solution:
46XY DSD - a genotypical male with female phenotype- along with hypertension makes the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency more likely.

Clinical profile in 17-hydroxylase deficiency:

Aldosterone excess: Salt retention, hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hypertension.

Sex steroid deficiency: In contrast to 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, patients with 17-hydroxylase deficiency are unable to synthesize sex hormones. Affected males are incompletely virilized (male pseudo-hermaphroditism/ ambiguous genitalia 46XY) and there is a failure of sexual development in affected females.

Cortisol deficiency is not manifested, as elevated corticosterone is an active glucocorticoid.

Intersex or DSD means a condition in which development of chromosomal, gonadal, or anatomical sex is atypical. There is a greater incidence of gender dissatisfaction, gender non-conformity, gender fluidity in such individuals.

questions.text: An infant with hypospadias, bifid scrotum presents with signs and symptoms of salt wasting. Lab reports reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxy pregnenolone and dehydroepiandrosterone. Which of the following deficiency would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of incomplete virilization (hypospadias with or without bifid scrotum and cryptorchidism), salt wasting due to cortisol and aldosterone deficiency, and elevated dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and 17 hydroxy pregnenolone levels are suggestive of 3 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. 

Clinical profile in 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (3β-HSD):

  • Aldosterone deficiency- Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and acidosis)
  • Cortisol deficiency- Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), and shock
  • Androgen deficiency- Males are incompletely virilized (male pseudo-hermaphroditism/ambiguous genitalia 46XY/hypogonadism, cryptorchidism)
  • Excess DHEA (weak androgen)- Females are mildly virilized (acne, hirsutism).

questions.text: The most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension among the following is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension is 11β-hydroxylase deficiency causing congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

Hypertension in CAH is due to 11β-hydroxylase deficiency followed by 17-hydroxylase deficiency.

Cortisol and aldosterone deficiency cannot be manifested because some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone, and hence, there are no signs of adrenal insufficiency. 

21- hydroxylase deficiency causes salt-wasting resulting in hypotension.

questions.text: A boy presents with precocious puberty and hypertension to your OPD. The estimation of ______ will help in the diagnosis of CAH.
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty in a male with hypertension is suggestive of CAH due to 11β-hydroxylase deficiency. An increase in 11-deoxycortisol levels is diagnostic of the enzyme deficiency.

11β-hydroxlase catalyzes the convertion of deoxycortisol to cortisol. Therefore, 11β-hydroxlase deficiency causes an increase in 11 deoxycortisol levels.

questions.text: On a vacation trip to Hawaii, a father was helping his 7-year-old son change into swimming trunks.  He noticed the presence of pubic and axillary hair. He knew it was abnormal and brought the child to the pediatrician.  Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of pubic and axillary hair in a seven-year-old boy is suggestive of precocious puberty and 17-Hydroxylase deficiency is least likely to cause it. 

In 17-hydroxylase deficiency, patients are unable to synthesize sex hormones, and hence the affected males are incompletely virilized and present as phenotypic females (but gonads are usually palpable in the inguinal region or the labia).


In both 21-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase deficiencies, the respective precursors to the hormones are shunted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in all the signs and symptoms of androgen excess, including virilization of female and precocious puberty in males.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as _______.
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism as the most common enzyme deficiency is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia resembles a male's.

The image below shows ambiguous genitalia in a female with CAH:

The mechanism underlying the endocrine defects in 21-hydroxylase deficiency is depicted in the image below:

Babies with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present around 10-14 days of age with the subset of symptoms due to aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency and androgen excess.

Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises marked by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis.

Cortisol deficiency causes manifestations like hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.

Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency results in virilization of females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency resulting in incomplete virilization. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is 2nd most common enzyme affected in CAH.

Option C: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development(DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

Option D: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency,  17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.text: A postgraduate examines a female baby in late infancy with failure to thrive. The genitalia appears normal. Reports reveal serum sodium of 125 MEq/L and serum K+ of 6.5 MEq/L. Estimation of which of the following hormones will be helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of failure to thrive in late infancy, normal genitalia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia suggests aldosterone synthase deficiency. Estimation of aldosterone levels will help in the diagnosis.

Normal genitalia in female children rules out congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) caused by 21-hydroxylase and 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia rule out CAH due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency and 11β-hydroxylase deficiency. 

 

Infants with aldosterone synthase deficiency may have severe electrolyte abnormalities with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic
acidosis.

Since cortisol synthesis is unaffected, infants rarely become as ill as untreated infants with salt-losing forms of CAH. So some infants escape diagnosis at birth because of normal cortisol levels.

Later in infancy or in early childhood, they may exhibit failure to thrive and poor growth. 

Adults often are asymptomatic, although they may develop electrolyte abnormalities when depleted of sodium through procedures such as bowel preparation for a barium enema.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with obesity and short stature, with signs of abnormal masculinization as shown below. Which statement regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Most common cause is adrenocortical tumor
Hypertension seen here can occasionally lead to heart failure
Generalized obesity is a common finding in younger children.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing round face (moon facies), obesity, abnormal masculinization, and purple skin striae are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. The most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids, not an adrenocortical tumor.

Cushing's syndrome is characterized excess glucocorticoids that can be due to:

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an ACTH–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features in children:

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A high school girl Meenu presents to you with anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness for the past few months. On examination, she had the finding shown in the image. Which of the following will not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Addison's disease and hypertension is not seen here. 

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency due to acquired lesions of the adrenal cortex, which prevent the production of cortisol and, often, aldosterone. Hence, due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, there will be hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. 

The deficiency of cortisol stimulates the production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Increased ACTH leads to diffuse hyperpigmentation, including areas not exposed to the sun, such as buccal mucosa and gums.

Addison’s disease is characterized by the following:

  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Increased ACTH levels
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Hyperpigmentation

ACTH stimulation test (cosyntropin) - Low cortisol levels before and after administration of ACTH are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency, Addison's disease.

questions.text: You have been called to see a 10-year-old child in the emergency room with complaints of fever and vomiting for the past three days. On examination the child had tachycardia and there was significant postural hypotension. Upon investigation, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia were present. You suspect adrenal insufficiency.  Which of the following is the most likely organism grown in blood culture?
questions.solution:
The most common infectious etiology for adrenal insufficiency in children is meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome:
Adrenal apoplexy due to fulminant bacterial infection (most common Meningococcus).

Clinical features: Non-specific like fever, rigors, vomiting, headache, disseminated intravascular coagulation (large petechial rashes in the skin and mucous membrane), hypotension, and septic shock

Petechial rashes in meningococcal infection:

 

Most commons in adrenal insufficiency:

  • The most common infectious cause of Addison's disease in India is tuberculosis.
  • The most common cause of adrenal insufficiency is the sudden withdrawal of steroids in a patient on long-term steroid therapy.
  • The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in children is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).
  • The most common antigen against which antibodies are found in Addison's disease is CYP 21 (21-hydroxylase).

questions.text: In the pediatric ward,  a resident is evaluating a case of primary adrenal insufficiency who has failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification is noted radiologically. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wolman's disease.

It is a rare lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) that leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs.

Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

questions.text: You are evaluating a case of hyperpigmentation. The patient reports having undergone bilateral adrenalectomy a few years back for Cushing's disease. MRI shows an enlargement of the pituitary adenoma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of hyperpigmentation, history of bilateral adrenalectomy and MRI showing enlarged pituitary adenoma points to the diagnosis of Nelson's syndrome. 

Nelson's syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.

The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or formation of a new one.

Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Excessive ACTH secretion
  • Corticotroph adenoma

Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.

The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

Option B: Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease. It affects the brainstem and basal ganglia. 

Option C: Hamman-Rich syndrome also known as acute interstitial pneumonia, is a rare and severe form of idiopathic interstitial lung disease.

Option D: Job syndrome, also known as hyper-IgE syndrome is an autosomal dominant immunodeficiency disorder. It occurs as a result of STAT3 mutation leading to deficiency in the IL-17 producing T cells. This results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils to sites of infection.

questions.text: Using novel chemiluminescence immunoassay techniques, you measure the hormonal profile of the adrenal gland of a normal fetus. Which of the following would be present in higher concentrations?
questions.solution:
The fetal adrenal gland produces a maximum amount of DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone).

DHEA and DHEA-S serve as estrogen precursors. The maternal adrenal gland does not produce a sufficient amount of DHEA-S. The fetal adrenal glands are quantitatively the most important source of placental estrogen precursors in pregnancy. During most of gestation, the fetal adrenal gland is almost solely dedicated to the production of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate DHEAS.

questions.text: A woman has a previous child with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. In the present pregnancy, steroid therapy should be started _______

choices.text: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
After karyotyping and determination of sex of the baby

questions.solution:
Mothers with pregnancies at risk (previously affected child) of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) should be started with steroid therapy as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed.

Dexamethasone 20 μg/kg is started to suppress the secretion of steroids by the fetal adrenals (including adrenal androgens) and prevent the virilization of the external genitals in affected females.

Then, chorionic villus biopsy is performed to determine the sex and genotype of the fetus and therapy is continued only if the fetus is an affected female.

 

The drug used for prenatal therapy in CAH is dexamethasone, which is avoided if the fetus is known to be male or an unaffected female.

questions.text: You see a newborn with an enlarged clitoris and partially fused labia. You also note features such as frontal bossing, brachycephaly, midface hypoplasia, slender fingers, medial bowing of ulna, and heart abnormalities. Investigation reveals a deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of P450 oxidoreductase (POR) along with the given findings are suggestive of Antley-Bixler syndrome. 

Features of Antley–Bixler syndrome:

These include deficiencies of 17-hydroxylase and 21-hydroxylase along with other congenital anomalies.

It leads to under virilization of males and virilisation of females via an alternate pathway. Virilization of mother is seen because of decreased placental aromatase activity leading to excess androgens in fetus and mother. 

 Congenital anomalies seen are as follows:

  • Head and face: Craniosynostosis, brachycephaly, frontal bossing, severe midface hypoplasia, with proptosis and choanal atresia.
  • Limbs: Humeroradial synostosis; medial bowing of the ulnas; long, slender fingers, with camptodactyly and anterior bowing of the femurs.
  • Malformations of the heart and kidneys.
